key_insights: The distinction between acceptance and resignation may lie in energy availability - acceptance leaves energy for other possibilities while resignation creates absence
Authentic acceptance can feel alive even in difficulty, contrasted with the numbness of resignation
Genuine acceptance sometimes requires surrender that looks identical to resignation from the outside
The direction of attention may be crucial - acceptance attends to what is, while resignation turns away
open_questions: What allows aliveness to remain present when accepting something difficult?
How can therapists discern between acceptance and resignation when they appear identical externally?
What keeps energy flowing rather than shutting down during difficult acceptance?
threads_explored: The phenomenological difference between acceptance and resignation in therapeutic contexts
The role of bodily felt sense and energy states in distinguishing internal experiences
The paradox of surrender that can lead to either acceptance or resignation
